vjdbv0.3_description: GenBank Accession of the virus sequence. It equals NCBI Accession, ENA Accession, and DDBJ Accession, which are part of the INSDC.
NCBI Assembly Accession of the sequence.
References the BioProject Accession that the virus sequence is a part of (INSDC). Also BioProject Accession of the host of the prophages.
References the BioSample Accession that the virus sequence is a part of (INSDC).
Date when the sample the sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct

vjdbv0.3_description: Country or sea area where the sample the sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of countries, provided by the INSDC

vjdbv0.3_description: Genbank title of the sequence.
Determines if this sequence is available in Genbank.
Determines if this sequence is a reference sequence in the RefSeq database.
City where the sample the sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
Country name and additional identifier like a state abbreviation from where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of countries, provided by the INSDC: State or similar closer region(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Common name of the host the virus sequence was collected from, e.g. human.
Length of the sequence in basepairs (bp) from NCBI Virus|BVBRC.
Molecule type of the sequence, e.g. ssRNA. Note that there are 15 molecule types corresponding to combinations of the Baltimore Classifications.
Wether the sequence is a partial or complete sequence from NCBI.
The level of the sequence completeness compare to the representative sequence in refseq in percentage
GenBank organism name, a taxonomic name at species level or below the species level.
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text; Should be species level or below(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Organization the submitter(s) is(are) affiliated with.
vjdb_example: National Center for Biotechnology Information, NIH

vjdbv0.3_description: Date when the sequence was made public in a repository (e.g. GenBank, BV-BRC).
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Name of the virus segment. Can be a number.
NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) accession ID.
Submitter name(s) of the sequence.
Tissue, Specimen or Source of the host from which the sample the sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
State/Region where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
ENA analysis object accession ID.
The level of the Assembly (contig, scaffold, chromosome, complete genome).
Minimum length of consecutive Ns to be considered a gap.
The program used for genome assembly.
Identifier on how to treat the submitted assembly. Currently only assemblies from ‘clone or isolate’ are permitted.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, for submissions it is always "clone or isolate"(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Accession of the sequence in the BV-BRC database.
Name of the institution/affiliation to which the person collecting the sample belongs
Health state of the host at the time of sample collection, e.g. diseased or healthy
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The geographic location by latitude, where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. (DD)
vjdb_validation_rules: Coordinates in DD format. Decimal number between  -90 and 90. 90 and -90 work without decimals.

vjdbv0.3_description: The geographic location by longitude, where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. (DD)
vjdb_validation_rules: Coordinates in DD format. Decimal number between  -180 and 180. 180 and -180 work without decimals.

vjdbv0.3_description: Continent where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Describes the physical, environmental or local geographical source of the sample, e.g. soil
Name of the person that collected the sample
The cuttoff used to determine if the sample is seropositive.
References an ENA assembly to an ENA Experiment.
Natural behaviour of the sampled host.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The hosts main disease diagnosis.
The hosts disease outcome. Did the host recover from the disease?
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
The host's broader group association in a taxonomic context from BV-BRC.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the BVBRC(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Natural habitat of the avian or mammalian host
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: BVBRC Lab Host, common name of the lab host.
The lab hosts NCBI Taxonomy ID.
The lab hosts scientific species name.
The sampled host's scientific species name.
The host sequence NCBI Taxonomy ID. Can be based on the mapping by GTDB of the GTDB Species Name to the NCBI Taxonomy ID.
vjdb_validation_rules: Whole number value. Defined by the NCBI Taxonomy

vjdbv0.3_description: The sampled hosts sex from the BV-BRC.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The sampled hosts unique ID by which it can be referred to.
Method used to assess if a sample if flu positive/negative. When multiple once were used they are seperated by semicolon.
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text (Methods) seperated by semicolon, no quotes

vjdbv0.3_description: Result of the given methods. Positive(P) or Negative(N). For multiple test the results are delimited by semicolon, e.g. P; P.
vjdb_validation_rules: P(positive)/N(negative) divided by semicolons matching the number and place of the corresponding test method, no quotes.

vjdbv0.3_description: Influenza virus type classification, A, B or C.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Determines if this sequence is available in BV-BRC.
The test result for other tested pathogens given as described by influenza test result.
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text (Methods) seperated by semicolon, no quotes. See also Influenza Test Method

vjdbv0.3_description: Was the sample tested for other pathogens? Insert the pathogenic organisms using semicolon as a delimiter, e.g. Newcastle. “None” is also valid.
vjdb_validation_rules: P(positive)/N(negative)/not applicable divided by semicolons matching the number and place of the corresponding test method, no quotes.

vjdbv0.3_description: Lineage determined by Pangolin.
Pangolin version used to determine the lineage.
If the sample was only received and not collected provide the receipt date.
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: RKI Accession of the virus sequence.
References a ENA assembly to an ENA Run object.
The virus species NCBI Taxonomy ID.
vjdb_validation_rules: Whole number value. Defined by the NCBI Taxonomy

vjdbv0.3_description: Serological variety of a species characterised by its antigenic properties, e.g. H1N1.
Common abbreviations of the virus species name.
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text, common virus name abbreviations were collected by the ICTV

vjdbv0.3_description: temprory NCBI Tax ID used for mapping taxonoly tree to metadata table
Average sequencing depth across the sequence from BVBRC.
vjdb_validation_rules: Decimal number value followed by an x(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Percentage of G and C nucleotides in the sequence from BVBRC.
vjdb_validation_rules: Decimal number value, describes a percentage(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Percentage of Ns within the whole sequence.
Generic name of the sequence (Name of the entry).
Number of contigs in the sequence.
The doi of the sequences publication paper.
The pubmed ID of the sequences publication paper.
Last update date of the sequence in BVBRC (whole entry).
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Version of the sequence (whole entry).
Institution that sequenced the collected sample.
Insert size for paired reads.
Instrument model used for sequencing.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The protocol used to construct the sequencing library.
The design of the sequencing library including details of how it was constructed.
The sequencing library layout specifies whether to expect single or paired configuration of reads.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The name for the sequencing library if any.
The method used to select for or against, enrich, or screen the material being sequenced.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The library source specifies the type of source material that is being sequenced.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The sequencing technique intended for this sequencing library.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Instrument platform used for sequencing, multiple are seperated (only for assemblies).
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Why was the collected sample sequenced?
The name of the source database or tool of the virus sequence.
Country of the submitter's organization.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of countries, provided by the INSDC

vjdbv0.3_description: Region or location of the organization of the submitters.
VirJenDB sequence ID of the virus sequence.
VirJenDB metadata version
Unique ID given by the investigator as strain might not be unique.
Antiviral treatment used for this subject, such as zanamavir oseltamivir, amantadine.
Dosage of the treatment taken by the subject. example: 0.05 mg.
vjdb_validation_rules: Decimal number value followed by an empty space and the unit(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Duration of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days.example: 5.
Initiation of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days. example: 2.5.
The run data file model.
The name or relative pathname of a run data file.
Whether or not the subject is gravid. if so, report date due or date post-conception and specify which of these two dates is being reported.
vjdb_validation_rules: yes/no, if yes provide post conception date or date due with carification which one it is(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Was the subject confined to a hospital as a result of virus infection or problems occurring secondary to virus infection?
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Other descriptive information relating to the host.
The number of days the illness lasted. example: 4
Date the subject showed an onset of symptoms. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2011-10-20
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
vjdb_example: fever; headache; malaise; myalgia; nausea; runny_nose
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text, symptoms seperated by semicolon

vjdbv0.3_description: Unique number of the strain which is reported as a part of the influenza strain name, such as a/chicken/fujian/411/2002(hxn1). format: integer number, example: 411
Date that the influenza vaccination was administered to the subject over the past year. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2007-05-12
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Influenza vaccinations that have been administered to the subject over the last year. example: 2009 h1n1 flumist

vjdbv0.3_name: Influenza-like Illness at the Time of Sample Collection
vjdbv0.3_description: Is the subject at the time of sample collection considered to have influenza like illness?
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Dose used for the inoculoation experiment.
Brief description of the protocol inoculation route.
Is the virus stock used for the inoculation available?
Does the h1n1 influenza virus originate from a swine-like outbreak (as opposed to a seasonal flu)?
Description helping to explain what the cut off value means.
Number of host individuals inoculated for the experiment.
Use of personal protective equipment, such as gloves, gowns, during any type of exposure. example: mask
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text, multiple values seperated by semicolon

vjdbv0.3_description: Reason for the sample collection.
vjdb_example: active surveillance in response to outbreak; market sample
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location. in soil context: explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before dna extraction (fresh/frozen/other).
Free-form text describing the sample, its origin, and its method of isolation.
Designation of information related to vaccination history as self reported or documented.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: Name of the strain from which the sample was obtained.
Briefly describes the goals, purpose, and scope of the study.  this need not be listed if it can be inherited from a referenced publication.
Exposure of the subject to infected human or animals, such as poultry, wild bird or swine. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon. example: poultry; wild bird
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text, multiple values seperated by semicolon

vjdbv0.3_description: Duration of the exposure of the subject to an infected human or animal. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their duration in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: 1 day; 0.33 days (Units: year)
vjdb_validation_rules: Decimal number value followed by an empty space and the unit(!). If there are multiple values in Subject Exposure field add equally may fields here in the same order as Subject Exposure(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Clear and useful title of the study/ project, e.g. a title usable for a publication or the purpose of the project and its timeframe.
Clear and useful title to identify the sequencing experiment. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.
Clear and useful title to identify the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.

Setting within which the subject is exposed to animals, such as farm, slaughterhouse, food preparation. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their type in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: backyard flock; confined animal feeding operation
vjdb_example: backyard flock; confined animal feeding operation
vjdb_validation_rules: Free text, multiple values seperated by semicolon. If there are multiple values in Subject Exposure field add equally may fields here in the same order as Subject Exposure(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Dosage of the vaccine taken by the host. example: 0.05 ml
vjdb_validation_rules: Decimal number value followed by an empty space and the unit(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Lot number of the vaccine.
Manufacturer of the vaccine.

vjdbv0.3_name: WHO/OIE/FAO Clade (Required for HPAI H5N1 Viruses)
vjdbv0.3_description: Who/oie/fao clade should be included for highly pathogenic h5n1 viruses. example: 2.2
Collection of outdated names for a particular virus.
Byte range data of the sample in the sequence file without the header
The file location of the multiseq fasta file including the parent folder name
Date of the insertion into the VirJen database
The last date the metadata was updated in the VirJen database.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the ICTV. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the ICTV does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the NCBI. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the NCBI does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the NCBI.

The genotype or subtype of a virus sequence, as provided by the sequence submitter. This field comes from the "/serotype" field of the GenBank record and is shown as submitted. Consistency and accuracy may vary.
Individual isolate from which the sample was obtained.
Host age given by a number. Is connected to Host Age Unit. The number should match the unit. E.g. 2 years
Unit that describes the host age. Is connected to Host Age. Should fit the number, e.g. 2 years
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the VJDB

vjdbv0.3_description: Host Ages in a uniform unit, tba
Host age number only from "BVBRC Host Age": not yet standardized!
Indicator that sequences came from samples from a laboratory setting, and not from a wild host.
NCBI TaxIDs of the virus' taxonomy from BVBRC.
Aggregation of the NCBI Taxonomy Names of the virus lineage.
Aggregation of the ICTV Taxonomy Names of the virus lineage.
This accession is a representative of the species in the ICTV Taxonomy.
There is one page in Viralzone for this Taxon ID
The ICTV Host source field content to be combined with other host group data from the other sources.
ICTV ID from Master_Species_List file
Commonly used virus name (or names separated by a semi-colon).
Host Age and Unit from BV-BRC.

vjdbv0.3_name: Hash content for the rank in taxonomy tree
vjdbv0.3_description: N/A
A flag that indicates if the record is the latest update in VirJenDB database
The list of the fields and their content when they are updated in each release in compare to the previous version
Clear and useful title to identify the analysis of your sequencing experiment. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.
References the Host GTDB Species Name to which the NCBI host taxonomy ID of the virus sequence could be mapped.
N/A
N/A
If the sequence is a representative for a group of identical VirJenDB sequences.
The VirJenDB Accession for the unique representative sequence. For the non-phages, the smallest Accession in the group. See documentation for selection details.
If the sequence is a representative sequence of a group of sequences, computed by VClust.
The VirJenDB Accession of the representative of its cluster. See documentation for selection details.
The tool or database that predicted the sequence. No value means that it is not a predicted sequence.
Host Assembly Accession of the sequence (INSDC).
Host Accession from the GenBank that can refer to the host sequence (not the prophage).
The program used for host genome assembly.
References the BioProject Accession that the host sequence is a part of (INSDC).
References the BioSample Accession that the host sequence is a part of (INSDC).
Country or sea area where the sample the host sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of countries, provided by the INSDC

vjdbv0.3_description: Date when the sample the host sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
vjdb_validation_rules: YYYY-MM-DD; Some browsers can display dates in a different format, but it is still correct

vjdbv0.3_description: References the Host IMGM Taxon OID from which the virus sequence was extracted by IMG/VR.
phage id internal identifier
Average sequencing depth across the host sequence from IMG/VR|PhiSpy|PhD.
vjdb_validation_rules: Decimal number value followed by an x(!)

vjdbv0.3_description: Instrument platform used for host sequencing, multiple are seperated (only for assemblies).
vjdb_validation_rules: Defined list of values, provided by the ENA

vjdbv0.3_description: The list of the hash for the lineage of the rank in ICTV VMR file
Taxonomy Table Hash ID of the Parent Rank
Taxonomy Table Hash ID of the Rank
ICTV Rank Name
ICTV Rank Name
N/A
